body:
This post is part of our special coverage of Egypt Protests 2011.

Egyptians are known for their strong sense of humour, even in their darkest hour. The ongoing revolution has had its fair share of laughs both on protesters' banners and via jokes circulating online.

From Saudi Arabia @TurkiAldakhil tweeted:
 #fun25jan عظمة المصريين بسخريتهم في أحلك المواقف. لنجمع النكات والتعليقات الساخرة حول الأحداث في الهاش تاق السابق. فضلا
 The greatness of Egyptians is their ability to joke even in the darkest hour. We can collect jokes and funny comments about the ongoing events via this tag. #fun25jan
Reacting to the government's accusation that the instigators of the revolution are foreign agents @SamehWagdy made a humorous satirical reference to the fictional characters in Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles saying:
 عاجل: تم القبض على 2 عملاء ايطالين و 1 ياباني في التحرير يحملون السلاح. بعد أن تم
استجوابهم: ليوناردو, رافايلو. و الياباني طلع المعلم رشدان
 Urgent: 2 Italian and 1 Japanese foreign agents have been arrested. In interrogation [the Italians] said they were named Leonardo and Raphael. The Japanese guy was Splinter.
@Lubbaz commented on Egyptian President Mubarak's refusal to step down:
 New word added to Dictionary: #Mubarak (v.): To stick something. Example: I will mubarak this paper to the wall !! LoooL #JAN25 #egypt
@Abdullah_SH joked about the hypocrisy of Egyptian state television showing no protesters, whilst poking fun at Al Jazeera television for exaggerating protestor numbers:
 

الجزيره : ملايين المتظاهرين فى ميدان التحرير , العربية: مئات الالاف , التلفزيون المصرى: ألوف المتظاهرين , مبارك: أنا مش شايف حد !! #fun25jan


 Aljazeera: Millions of people in Tahrir Square. AlArabya TV: Hundred thousands. Egyptian TV: few thousands. Mubarak: I can't see anybody. #Fun25jan
This famous banner can be seen in Tahrir Square, held by a young man who has not left for 10 continuous days:

[caption id="attachment_193059" align="aligncenter" width="225" caption="Banner reads: "You will leave, you will leave. So please hurry up, I want to cut my hair"."][/caption]

@mado_1 took the picture below showing how people are cooperating to read newspapers in Tahrir Square.

[caption id="attachment_193062" align="aligncenter" width="225" caption="People invent a way to read newspapers collectively. Twitpic by @mado_1"][/caption]
 @Ramy Raouf took this shot of someone trying to send a clear message of his demands:


[caption id="attachment_193234" align="aligncenter" width="375" caption="Banner reads: "Leave means go away". Photo by Flickr user RamyRaoof (CC BY 2.0)."][/caption]

@3mr83 tweeted this picture of protestors, joking they were imitating ancient Spartan battle scenes from the movie '300'.

[caption id="attachment_193238" align="aligncenter" width="375" caption="Imitating the movie '300'. Twitpic by @3mr83."][/caption]

Replying to the accusation by the government that those in Tahrir Square are foreign agents who are being fed by KFC, comes this picture by Shady Isaac on Facebook:

[caption id="attachment_193311" align="aligncenter" width="375" caption="Protesters made a corner for food they bought themselves and labeled it “Here is KFC”. Picture by Shady Isaac on Facebook."][/caption]

Mohamed Tawfiq manages to capture pictures of the pain:

[caption id="attachment_193329" align="aligncenter" width="375" caption="Banner reads: "Leave please, my shoulders hurt me". Photo by Mohamed Tawfiq on Facebook."][/caption]

[caption id="attachment_193330" align="aligncenter" width="218" caption="Banner reads: "Go away please, my hands are hurting". Photo by Mohamed Tawfiq on Facebook."][/caption]

People have been taking shelter from the rain under army tanks, captured in this Twitpic by @Abol3araby:

[caption id="attachment_193386" align="aligncenter" width="375" caption="Sleeping under an Egyptian army tank. Twitpic by @Abol3araby."][/caption]

 شباب مصر تحت الدبابة وقت المطر .. منظر بمليون جنيه #jan25 #Egypt #25jan
 TRANSLATION
And finally - revolution or not - the wedding went on for this happy couple, image courtesy of @tololy:

[caption id="attachment_193351" align="aligncenter" width="375" caption="MUST-SEE: The wedding must go on! Tahrir square for our honeymoon <3 #Egypt #Jan25 #ArabProtest. Picture by @tololy from Yfrog."][/caption]

This post is part of our special coverage of Egypt Protests 2011.

title: Egypt: Humour in the Midst of Revolution
